title: UCI Gravel World Championships tech gallery: [Redacted] bikes win both elite races
content:
Cyclist
UCI Gravel World Championships tech gallery: [Redacted] bikes win both elite races

The UCI Gravel World Championships not only has thrilling racing (probably), but also a wealth of cool, interesting and new bike tech. After the much-criticised first edition was rideable on road bikes, with men’s winner Gianni Vermeersch and Mathieu van der Poel doing the business on Canyon Ultimates, the 2023 races were primarily ridden on gravel bikes. That’s as sure sign as you need that the route was much improved.

We got photographer James York to go snooping before he went on the course to shoot both races. Here are our favourites of what he found.

Related Posts

UCI Gravel World Championships 2023 race galleries: Almost a roaring success

Pinarello Dogma X review: First ride on Pinarello’s new top-tier endurance bike

Unbound Gravel pro bike: Danni Shrosbree’s Factor Ostro Gravel

UCI Gravel World Championships tech gallery: Variation and improvisation

USA pro gravel racer Sarah Sturm has the nicest bike design in cycling (and kit, though obviously she was in national colours for this race). We featured it last year and her colourful Specialized Crux was back albeit with wider tyres. She opted for 42mm Specialized Pathfinder Pros and a SRAM mullet drivetrain with a 44T front chainring and a huge cassette. She shared her full set-up on her Instagram.

Most importantly though, Sturm matched her nails to her bike.

Sturm was the second American on the day, finishing an impressive 16th.

Factor Ostro Gravel bike, Quoc Gran Tourer XC shoes, Precision Fuel and Hydration bottles, it could only be Britain’s Danni Shrosbree. She opted for a 2× Shimano GRX drivetrain with a 48/31 crankset.

Shrosbree was hit with bad luck on the day and revealed on her Instagram that she went over a nail on the course that cracked her rim.

GB teammate Maddy Nutt was running 1× GRX Di2 with a 40t chainring and a 10-50t cassette on her ‘Stone Edition’ Ribble Gravel SL with Parcours Ronde wheels.

Nutt also had this very cool custom top cap.

She also strapped a CO2 canister to her seatpost. Smart and aero.

Nutt went through her full set-up on her YouTube, which I highly recommend.

Bloody hell it’s Alain Prost. In among the age-groupers, the Formula 1 legend was competing for France and finished 18th in the 65+ category. Who needs Valtteri Bottas?

Lidl-Trek’s young Italian star Gaia Realini finished ninth on this Trek Domane with a SRAM Red groupset and 35mm Pirelli Cinturato Gravel tyres. We think she might’ve been nervous about punctures given the two sealant canisters strapped on.

Demi Vollering had one bottle strapped to her S-Works Crux, with help from SD Worx DS Lars Boom, who won the 2008 Cyclocross World Championships at Le Bandie Lake, where the races began this weekend.

Winner of the women’s race Kasia Niewiadoma was riding the as-yet-unreleased Canyon gravel bike – that was also ridden to victory at Unbound earlier in the year – with SRAM’s innovative new GX Eagle Transmission mountain bike groupset that does away with the derailleur hanger.

She was running a 46T 1× crankset and clearly got her set-up right, out-climbing everyone.

Another good angle of that hangerless derailleur.

Niewiadoma’s Canyon-SRAM teammate Tiffany Cromwell, who came home tenth, was also on the new Canyon and also ran with the Eagle Transmission groupset, although she opted for a 48t dinner plate single chainring.

There was an abundance of road pedals – not sure there was any danger of these lot walking – Cromwell going with Time.

Netherlands’ Lorena Wiebes, who finished fifth, had a similar set-up to SD Worx teammate Vollering, except her Crux had this lovely paintjob.

No Eagles for them though, Wiebes was running a 2× SRAM Red groupset.

And no surprise she went with Pathfinder tyres.

Denmark’s Movistar rider Emma Norsgaard, who was 24th on the day, had the SRAM Eagle Transmission on her Canyon with a 48t front chainring and a whopping cassette that went all the way to 50t.

What’s I think is interesting here is that this is definitely a Grail, you can see it written on the seatstay, but if you look at a full shot of the bike, it doesn’t look like the old Grail and certainly has the same handlebars as the new Canyon bike seen in all these other pictures. Plus, would a Canyon sponsored rider be given an old bike to ride? Not likely. So it’s probably safe to say this, as well as the other Canyons here, is a new Grail.

Spain and Movistar Classics and gravel specialist Ivan García Cortína’s race was derailed by a crash but he was on that new Canyon with lots of squeaky clean kit including a SRAM Red 1× groupset with 48t up front, Zipp 303 Firecrest wheels and Continental Terra Speed 40mm tyres.

He was using this lovely minimalist chain catcher.

Defending men’s champ Gianni Vermeersch swapped his Ultimate of last year for the new Canyon gravel bike this time around.

His Alpecin-Deceuninck team are Shimano-sponsored so he ran a Dura-Ace groupset with a 52/36 crankset.

First in 2022, 11th this time around.

Vermeersch paired his Shimano Dura-Ace C36 wheels with 35mm Vittoria Terreno Dry tyres – last year he had 33mm on the front and 35mm on the back.

Here’s where things get really interesting, Dutch rider Piotr Havik looks to be riding a pretty sensible Ridley Kanzo Fast.

But the closer you get the more interesting details you spot, like that chainring.

Or the Ceramic Speed oversized jockey wheel.

Plus chain catcher, Lezyne CO2 and handy Dynaplug attached to the bottle cage.

The 3D-printed Sella Italia Novus saddle is pretty cool too.

He also had a spare derailleur hanger taped onto his downtube.

Nathan Haas always gets a nice paintjob on his Colnago G3-X bikes.

German Martin Schätzl had some very funky Xentis carbon wheels on and finished three spots behind Havik – who had a big crash – in 69th.

Yes, the UCI were checking bikes for motors, this time Connor Swift’s newly launched Pinarello Dogma X endurance/all-road bike. Who needs a Grevil?

The men’s race was won by Matej Mohorič on this as-yet-unreleased Merida Silex (it helps that the name’s written on the downtube, thanks guys).

Mohorič clearly also didn’t fancy strapping anything to the new frame, opting for a nice little saddlebag.

We also enjoy what can only be a little drawing of a knife and fork for kilometre 96.

Brit Cameron Mason was riding his fourth World Championships race on the year having already ticked off Cyclocross, Mountain Bike XCM and XCO. He was riding this lovely S-Works Crux.

Mason was running this year’s new SRAM Force AXS.

Not everyone has full faith in tubeless just yet.

author: Will Strickson | Deputy Website Editor
